member.name: M:StardewValley.Objects.Furniture.GetAdditionalFurniturePlacementStatus(StardewValley.GameLocation,System.Int32,System.Int32,StardewValley.Farmer)

member.returns:
Returns one of these values:
0: valid placement.
1: the object is a wall placed object but isn't being placed on a wall.
2: the object can't be placed here due to the tile being marked as not furnishable.
3: the object isn't a wall placed object, but is trying to be placed on a wall.
4: the current location isn't decorable.
-1: general fail condition.

member.name: T:StardewValley.ArgUtility
member.summary: A utility for working with space-delimited or split argument lists.

member.name: M:StardewValley.ArgUtility.SplitBySpace(System.String)
member.summary: Split space-separated arguments in a string, ignoring extra spaces.
member.param: The value to split.
member.returns: Returns an array of the space-delimited arguments, or an empty array if the was null, empty, or only contains spaces.
member.remarks: For example, this text: A B C would be split into three values (A, B, and C). See also .

member.name: M:StardewValley.ArgUtility.SplitBySpace(System.String,System.Int32)
member.param: The value to split.
The number of arguments to return. Any remaining arguments by appended to the final argument.

member.summary: Split space-separated arguments in a string (ignoring extra spaces), and get a specific argument.
member.param: The value to split.
The index of the value to get.
The value to return if the is out of range for the array.
member.returns: Returns the value at the given index if the array was non-null and the index is in range, else the .

member.name: M:StardewValley.ArgUtility.SplitBySpaceQuoteAware(System.String)
member.summary: Split a list of space-separated arguments (ignoring extra spaces), with support for using quotes to protect spaces within an argument.
member.param: The value to split.
member.remarks: See remarks on for the quote format details.

member.name: M:StardewValley.ArgUtility.SplitQuoteAware(System.String,System.Char,System.StringSplitOptions,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Split a list of arguments using the given delimiter, with support for using quotes to protect delimiters within an argument.
member.param: The value to split.
The character on which to split the value. This shouldn't be a quote (") or backslash (\).
The string split options to apply for the delimiter split.

Whether to keep quotes and escape characters in the string. For example, the value Some \"test\" "here" would become Some "test" here if this disabled, or kept as-is (aside from splitting) if it's enabled. This impacts performance and should usually be false unless you need to split each value further while respecting quotes.

remarks.para: A quote in the text causes any delimiter to be ignored until the next quote. The quotes are removed from the string. For example, this comma-delimited input: "some,text",here will produce two values: some,text and here.

A quote character can be escaped by preceding it with a backslash (like \"). Escaped quotes have no effect on delimiters, and aren't removed from the string. For example, this comma-delimited input: some,\"text,here will produce three values: some, "text, and here. Remember that backslashes need to be escaped in C# or JSON strings (e.g. "\\" produces a single backslash).
See also which simplifies usage for the most common case used by the game.
When an input *doesn't* contain quotes, this is optimized to be almost as fast as just calling directly.

member.name: M:StardewValley.ArgUtility.UnsplitQuoteAware(System.String[],System.Char)
member.summary: Reverse a operation, producing a string which can safely be re-split.
member.param: The values to split.
The character on which to split the value. This shouldn't be a quote (") or backslash (\).

member.name: M:StardewValley.ArgUtility.EscapeQuotes(System.String)
member.summary: Escape quotes in a string so they're ignored by methods like .
member.param: The input string to escape.
member.remarks: This isn't idempotent (e.g. calling it twice will result in double-escaped quotes).

member.summary: Get whether an index is within the bounds of the array, regardless of what value is at that position.

member.name: T:StardewValley.Event.DefaultCommands
member.summary: The low-level event commands defined by the base game. Most code should use methods instead.
member.remarks: Every method within this class is an event command whose name matches the method name. All event commands must be static, public, and match .

member.remarks: Main format: temporaryAnimatedSprite texture rect_x rect_y rect_width rect_height animation_interval animation_length number_of_loops tile_x tile_y flicker flipped layer_depth alpha_fade scale scale_change rotation rotation_change. This also supports a number of extended options (like color Green).

member.name: M:StardewValley.Farmer.addItemToInventory(StardewValley.Item,System.Int32)
member.summary: Add an item to the player's inventory at a specific index position. If there's already an item at that position, the stacks are merged (if possible) else they're swapped.
member.param: The item to add.
The index position within the list at which to add the item.
member.returns: If the item was fully added to the inventory, returns null. If it replaced an item stack previously at that position, returns the replaced item stack. Else returns the input item with its stack reduced to the amount that couldn't be added.

member.summary: Add an item to the player's inventory if there's room for it, then show an animation of the player holding up the item above their head. If the item can't be fully added to the player's inventory, show (or queue) an item-grab menu to let the player collect the remainder.
member.param: The item to add.
The callback to invoke when the item is added to the player's inventory.
For any remainder that can't be added to the inventory directly, whether to add the item-grab menu to even if there's no active menu currently open.

member.name: F:StardewValley.Game1.version
member.summary: The semantic game version, like 1.6.0.

remarks.para: This mostly follows semantic versioning format with three or four numbers (without leading zeros), so 1.6.7 comes before 1.6.10. The first three numbers are consistent across all platforms, while some platforms may add a fourth number for the port version. This doesn't include tags like -alpha or -beta; see or for that.
Game versions can be compared using .

member.summary: The context for the item query which triggered this query, if any.

remarks.para: For example, LOST_BOOK_OR_ITEM RANDOM_ITEMS (O) contains a fallback RANDOM_ITEMS (O) query which is parsed if the player already found every lost book. In that case, the former is the parent context for the latter.

member.name: P:StardewValley.Item.ItemId
member.summary: A key which uniquely identifies the item data among others of the same type.

remarks.para: This identifies the item data, not the instance itself. For example, Wine and Pufferfish have different item IDs, but two instances of Wine have the same ID. Note that flavored items use the same ID as their base item (like Blueberry Wine and Wine).

This should only contain alphanumeric, underscore, and dot characters. This should be globally unique for custom items, but vanilla items may not be for legacy reasons; you can use instead as the globally unique ID.

member.name: M:StardewValley.Item.GetOneNew
member.summary: Called from to create a minimal instance of the same item type.
member.remarks:
Items are cloned in two steps:
is called on the original item to create a new instance of the same type.
is called on the new item to copy its values from the original.
This separation is needed to let subclasses extend the base copy logic without needing to duplicate it, so shouldn't copy any values beyond calling the constructor.

member.name: P:StardewValley.ItemTypeDefinitions.IItemDataDefinition.StandardDescriptor
member.summary: A legacy type identifier used in context tags.
member.remarks: All items have a context tag in the form id_{qualified id}. When this value is set, created items will also have an extra context tag in the form id_{descriptor}_{id}. This is intended to support some older item types, and isn't needed for newer item types which have unique item IDs.

member.name: T:StardewValley.Pathfinding.LocationWarpRoute
member.summary: A possible path through location names that NPCs can take while pathfinding.

member.name: F:StardewValley.Pathfinding.LocationWarpRoute.LocationNames
member.summary: The sequential location names that an NPC can pathfind through.

member.name: F:StardewValley.Pathfinding.LocationWarpRoute.OnlyGender
member.summary: If set, this route can only be used by NPCs of the given gender.

member.name: M:StardewValley.Pathfinding.LocationWarpRoute.#ctor(System.String[],System.Nullable{StardewValley.Gender})
member.summary: Construct an instance.
member.param: The sequential location names that an NPC can pathfind through.
If set, this route can only be used by NPCs of the given gender.

members.member: This class finds a path from one point to another using the A* pathfinding algorithm. Then it will guide the given character along that path. Can only be used on maps where the tile width and height are each 127 or less.

member.name: T:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache
member.summary: Handles pathfinding between locations.

member.name: F:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache.Routes
member.summary: Every possible path through location names that NPCs can take while pathfinding, indexed by the start location.
member.remarks: For example, "BusStop": [ "BusStop", "Town", "Mountain" ] means that an NPC in the bus stop can warp to town and then to the mountain.

member.name: F:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache.IgnoreLocationNames
member.summary: The location names which NPCs aren't allowed to warp through.
member.remarks: The farmhand cellars are added automatically.

member.name: F:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache.OverrideTargetNames
member.summary: A map of warp targets to the actual location name NPCs should warp to.

member.name: F:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache.GenderRestrictions
member.summary: The locations which can only be accessed by NPCs of one gender.

member.name: M:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache.PopulateCache
member.summary: Cache the possible pathfinding routes between game locations.

member.name: M:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache.GetLocationRoute(System.String,System.String,StardewValley.Gender)
member.summary: Get a valid pathfinding route between a start and destination location.
member.param: The name of the location the NPC is starting from.
The name of the destination location.
The NPC's gender, used to choose gender-specific routes like the pool locker rooms.
member.returns: If a valid route was found, returns a list of location names to transit through including the start and destination locations. For example, [ "BusStop", "Town", "Mountain" ] means that an NPC in the bus stop can warp to town and then to the mountain. If no valid route was found, returns null.

member.name: M:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache.ExploreWarpPoints(StardewValley.GameLocation,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String},System.Nullable{StardewValley.Gender})
member.summary: Recursively populate the cache based on every location reachable through warps starting from this location.
member.param: The location to start from.
The location names explored up to this point for the current route, excluding the .
The gender restriction for the route up to this point, if any. For example, a route which passes through the men's locker room is restricted to male NPCs.

member.name: M:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache.ExploreWarpPoints(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String},System.Nullable{StardewValley.Gender},System.Collections.Generic.HashSet{System.String})
member.summary: Recursively populate the cache based on every location reachable through warps starting from this location.
member.param: The location name to start from.
The location names explored up to this point for the current route, excluding the .
The gender restriction for the route up to this point, if any. For example, a route which passes through the men's locker room is restricted to male NPCs.
The warp target names which have already been explored from this location.
member.returns: Returns whether any routes were added.

member.name: M:StardewValley.Pathfinding.WarpPathfindingCache.AddRoute(System.Collections.Generic.List{System.String},System.Nullable{StardewValley.Gender})
member.summary: Add a route to the cache.
member.param: The location names in the route.
If set, this route can only be used by NPCs of the given gender.

member.name: F:StardewValley.SaveMigrations.SaveFixes.FixCropHarvestAmountsAndInferSeedIndex
member.summary: For Stardew Valley 1.4, update pre-1.4 crops to avoid yielding extra produce due to a fix in the crop yield calculation. This also infers the seed index, since the netSeedIndex value wasn't previously serialized to the save data.

member.name: F:StardewValley.SaveMigrations.SaveFixes.Leo6HeartGermanFix
member.summary: For Stardew Valley 1.5.2, fix an issue where a previous typo in the German localization prevented Leo from moving to the mainland after the 6-Heart event. This automatically adds the mail if any player has seen the event but the host doesn't have the mail.

member.name: F:StardewValley.SaveMigrations.SaveFixes.BirdieQuestRemovedFix
member.summary: For Stardew Valley 1.5.2, fix Birdie's quest being cancelable and re-add it if needed.

member.name: F:StardewValley.SaveMigrations.SaveFixes.SkippedSummit
member.summary: For Stardew Valley 1.5.2, if the farm is eternal, iterate through all players who are flagged as having seen the Summit event and remove the mail from anyone who hasn't heard the ending song. This will cause anyone who's playing the game with music muted to be able to re-visit the event (as well as anyone who skipped the event), but will at least ensure they get the song in their jukebox.

member.name: M:StardewValley.SaveMigrations.SaveMigrator_1_6.InferMachineInputOutputFields(StardewValley.Object)
member.summary: For a machine which contains output produced before 1.6, set the and values when possible. This ensures that some machine logic works as expected (e.g. crystalariums resuming on collect).
member.param: The machine which produced output.
member.remarks: This is heuristic, and some fields may not be set if it's not possible to retroactively infer them.

member.name: M:StardewValley.SaveMigrations.SaveMigrator_1_6.MigrateLegacyDescriptionElement(System.Lazy{System.Xml.Serialization.XmlSerializer},StardewValley.Quests.DescriptionElement)
member.summary: Migrate a pre-1.6 quest to the new format.
member.param: The XML serializer with which to serialize/deserialize and values.
The description element to migrate.
member.remarks:
This updates quest data for two changes in 1.6:
The way values are stored in the save XML changed from this:
<objective> <xmlKey>Strings\StringsFromCSFiles:SocializeQuest.cs.13802</xmlKey> <param> <anyType xsi:type="xsd:int">4</anyType> <anyType xsi:type="xsd:int">28</anyType> </param> </objective>
To this:
<objective> <xmlKey>Strings\StringsFromCSFiles:SocializeQuest.cs.13802</xmlKey> <param xsi:type="xsd:int">4</param> <param xsi:type="xsd:int">28</param> </objective>
If the given description element is affected, this method re-deserializes the data into the correct format.
Some translation keys were merged to fix gender issues.

member.name: P:StardewValley.TerrainFeatures.TerrainFeature.NeedsUpdate
member.summary: Whether this terrain feature's method should be called on each tick.

remarks.para: This is different from , which is implemented as part of .

In most cases, this should only be changed by the terrain feature itself, since disabling it may prevent logic like removal on destruction. For example, terrain features can set this to true when they need to be animated (e.g. shaken), and then set to false once the animation has completed.

member.returns: Returns true if the terrain feature should be removed, else false.

member.summary: Replaces spaces in the given text with a special character that lets you pass them into other space-delimited tokens. The characters are automatically turned back into spaces when displayed.
member.remarks: For example: [EscapedText Some arbitrary text].

member.name: M:StardewValley.TokenizableStrings.TokenParser.DefaultResolvers.GenderedText(System.String[],System.String@,System.Random,StardewValley.Farmer)
member.summary: Depending on the target player's gender, show either the male text or female text. To pass text containing spaces, wrap it in EscapeText.

member.name: T:Ionic.Crc.CRC32
member.summary: Computes a CRC-32. The CRC-32 algorithm is parameterized - you can set the polynomial and enable or disable bit reversal. This can be used for GZIP, BZip2, or ZIP.
member.remarks: This type is used internally by DotNetZip; it is generally not used directly by applications wishing to create, read, or manipulate zip archive files.

member.name: M:Ionic.Crc.CRC32.UpdateCRC(System.Byte,System.Int32)
member.summary: Process a run of N identical bytes into the CRC.

remarks.para: This method serves as an optimization for updating the CRC when a run of identical bytes is found. Rather than passing in a buffer of length n, containing all identical bytes b, this method accepts the byte value and the length of the (virtual) buffer - the length of the run.

member.param: the byte to include into the CRC.
the number of times that byte should be repeated.

member.summary: Combines the given CRC32 value with the current running total.
member.remarks: This is useful when using a divide-and-conquer approach to calculating a CRC. Multiple threads can each calculate a CRC32 on a segment of the data, and then combine the individual CRC32 values at the end.
member.param: the crc value to be combined with this one
the length of data the CRC value was calculated on

member.name: M:Ionic.Crc.CRC32.#ctor
member.summary: Create an instance of the CRC32 class using the default settings: no bit reversal, and a polynomial of 0xEDB88320.

member.name: M:Ionic.Crc.CRC32.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create an instance of the CRC32 class, specifying whether to reverse data bits or not.
member.param: specify true if the instance should reverse data bits.

remarks.para: In the CRC-32 used by BZip2, the bits are reversed. Therefore if you want a CRC32 with compatibility with BZip2, you should pass true here. In the CRC-32 used by GZIP and PKZIP, the bits are not reversed; Therefore if you want a CRC32 with compatibility with those, you should pass false.

member.name: M:Ionic.Crc.CRC32.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create an instance of the CRC32 class, specifying the polynomial and whether to reverse data bits or not.
member.param: The polynomial to use for the CRC, expressed in the reversed (LSB) format: the highest ordered bit in the polynomial value is the coefficient of the 0th power; the second-highest order bit is the coefficient of the 1 power, and so on. Expressed this way, the polynomial for the CRC-32C used in IEEE 802.3, is 0xEDB88320.
specify true if the instance should reverse data bits.

remarks.para: In the CRC-32 used by BZip2, the bits are reversed. Therefore if you want a CRC32 with compatibility with BZip2, you should pass true here for the reverseBits parameter. In the CRC-32 used by GZIP and PKZIP, the bits are not reversed; Therefore if you want a CRC32 with compatibility with those, you should pass false for the reverseBits parameter.

member.name: M:Ionic.Crc.CRC32.Reset
member.summary: Reset the CRC-32 class - clear the CRC "remainder register."

remarks.para: Use this when employing a single instance of this class to compute multiple, distinct CRCs on multiple, distinct data blocks.

member.name: T:Ionic.Crc.CrcCalculatorStream
member.summary: A Stream that calculates a CRC32 (a checksum) on all bytes read, or on all bytes written.

remarks.para: This class can be used to verify the CRC of a ZipEntry when reading from a stream, or to calculate a CRC when writing to a stream. The stream should be used to either read, or write, but not both. If you intermix reads and writes, the results are not defined.
This class is intended primarily for use internally by the DotNetZip library.

member.name: T:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream
member.summary: A class for compressing and decompressing GZIP streams.

remarks.para: The GZipStream is a Decorator on a . It adds GZIP compression or decompression to any stream.

Like the System.IO.Compression.GZipStream in the .NET Base Class Library, the Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream can compress while writing, or decompress while reading, but not vice versa. The compression method used is GZIP, which is documented in IETF RFC 1952, "GZIP file format specification version 4.3".
A GZipStream can be used to decompress data (through Read()) or to compress data (through Write()), but not both.

If you wish to use the GZipStream to compress data, you must wrap it around a write-able stream. As you call Write() on the GZipStream, the data will be compressed into the GZIP format. If you want to decompress data, you must wrap the GZipStream around a readable stream that contains an IETF RFC 1952-compliant stream. The data will be decompressed as you call Read() on the GZipStream.
Though the GZIP format allows data from multiple files to be concatenated together, this stream handles only a single segment of GZIP format, typically representing a single file.
This class is similar to and . ZlibStream handles RFC1950-compliant streams. handles RFC1951-compliant streams. This class handles RFC1952-compliant streams.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.Comment
member.summary: The comment on the GZIP stream.

remarks.para: The GZIP format allows for each file to optionally have an associated comment stored with the file. The comment is encoded with the ISO-8859-1 code page. To include a comment in a GZIP stream you create, set this property before calling Write() for the first time on the GZipStream.

When using GZipStream to decompress, you can retrieve this property after the first call to Read(). If no comment has been set in the GZIP bytestream, the Comment property will return null (Nothing in VB).

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.FileName
member.summary: The FileName for the GZIP stream.

remarks.para: The GZIP format optionally allows each file to have an associated filename. When compressing data (through Write()), set this FileName before calling Write() the first time on the GZipStream. The actual filename is encoded into the GZIP bytestream with the ISO-8859-1 code page, according to RFC 1952. It is the application's responsibility to insure that the FileName can be encoded and decoded correctly with this code page.

When decompressing (through Read()), you can retrieve this value any time after the first Read(). In the case where there was no filename encoded into the GZIP bytestream, the property will return null (Nothing in VB).

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.LastModified
member.summary: The last modified time for the GZIP stream.
member.remarks: GZIP allows the storage of a last modified time with each GZIP entry. When compressing data, you can set this before the first call to Write(). When decompressing, you can retrieve this value any time after the first call to Read().

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.Crc32
member.summary: The CRC on the GZIP stream.
member.remarks: This is used for internal error checking. You probably don't need to look at this property.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionMode)
member.summary: Create a GZipStream using the specified CompressionMode.

remarks.para: When mode is CompressionMode.Compress, the GZipStream will use the default compression level.

As noted in the class documentation, the CompressionMode (Compress or Decompress) also establishes the "direction" of the stream. A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress works only through Write(). A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Decompress works only through Read().

member.param: The stream which will be read or written.
Indicates whether the GZipStream will compress or decompress.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionMode,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel)
member.summary: Create a GZipStream using the specified CompressionMode and the specified CompressionLevel.

remarks.para: The CompressionMode (Compress or Decompress) also establishes the "direction" of the stream. A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress works only through Write(). A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Decompress works only through Read().

member.param: The stream to be read or written while deflating or inflating.
Indicates whether the GZipStream will compress or decompress.
A tuning knob to trade speed for effectiveness.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionMode,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a GZipStream using the specified CompressionMode, and explicitly specify whether the stream should be left open after Deflation or Inflation.

remarks.para: This constructor allows the application to request that the captive stream remain open after the deflation or inflation occurs. By default, after Close() is called on the stream, the captive stream is also closed. In some cases this is not desired, for example if the stream is a memory stream that will be re-read after compressed data has been written to it. Specify true for the parameter to leave the stream open.

The (Compress or Decompress) also establishes the "direction" of the stream. A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress works only through Write(). A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Decompress works only through Read().
The GZipStream will use the default compression level. If you want to specify the compression level, see .
See the other overloads of this constructor for example code.

member.param: The stream which will be read or written. This is called the "captive" stream in other places in this documentation.
Indicates whether the GZipStream will compress or decompress.
true if the application would like the base stream to remain open after inflation/deflation.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionMode,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a GZipStream using the specified CompressionMode and the specified CompressionLevel, and explicitly specify whether the stream should be left open after Deflation or Inflation.

remarks.para: This constructor allows the application to request that the captive stream remain open after the deflation or inflation occurs. By default, after Close() is called on the stream, the captive stream is also closed. In some cases this is not desired, for example if the stream is a memory stream that will be re-read after compressed data has been written to it. Specify true for the parameter to leave the stream open.

As noted in the class documentation, the CompressionMode (Compress or Decompress) also establishes the "direction" of the stream. A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress works only through Write(). A GZipStream with CompressionMode.Decompress works only through Read().

member.param: The stream which will be read or written.
Indicates whether the GZipStream will compress or decompress.
true if the application would like the stream to remain open after inflation/deflation.
A tuning knob to trade speed for effectiveness.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.BufferSize
member.summary: The size of the working buffer for the compression codec.

remarks.para: The working buffer is used for all stream operations. The default size is 1024 bytes. The minimum size is 128 bytes. You may get better performance with a larger buffer. Then again, you might not. You would have to test it.
Set this before the first call to Read() or Write() on the stream. If you try to set it afterwards, it will throw.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.GZipStream.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Dispose the stream.

remarks.para: This may or may not result in a Close() call on the captive stream. See the constructors that have a leaveOpen parameter for more information.

This method may be invoked in two distinct scenarios. If disposing == true, the method has been called directly or indirectly by a user's code, for example via the public Dispose() method. In this case, both managed and unmanaged resources can be referenced and disposed. If disposing == false, the method has been called by the runtime from inside the object finalizer and this method should not reference other objects; in that case only unmanaged resources must be referenced or disposed.

member.param: indicates whether the Dispose method was invoked by user code.

member.summary: Write data to the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the GZipStream to compress data while writing, you can create a GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that GZipStream, providing uncompressed data as input. The data sent to the output stream will be the compressed form of the data written.
A GZipStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both. Writing implies compression. Reading implies decompression.

member.name: T:Ionic.Zlib.FlushType
member.summary: Describes how to flush the current deflate operation.
member.remarks: The different FlushType values are useful when using a Deflate in a streaming application.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.FlushType.None
member.summary: No flush at all.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.FlushType.Partial
member.summary: Closes the current block, but doesn't flush it to the output. Used internally only in hypothetical scenarios. This was supposed to be removed by Zlib, but it is still in use in some edge cases.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.FlushType.Sync
member.summary: Use this during compression to specify that all pending output should be flushed to the output buffer and the output should be aligned on a byte boundary. You might use this in a streaming communication scenario, so that the decompressor can get all input data available so far. When using this with a ZlibCodec, AvailableBytesIn will be zero after the call if enough output space has been provided before the call. Flushing will degrade compression and so it should be used only when necessary.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.FlushType.Full
member.summary: Use this during compression to specify that all output should be flushed, as with FlushType.Sync, but also, the compression state should be reset so that decompression can restart from this point if previous compressed data has been damaged or if random access is desired. Using FlushType.Full too often can significantly degrade the compression.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.FlushType.Finish
member.summary: Signals the end of the compression/decompression stream.

member.name: T:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel
member.summary: The compression level to be used when using a DeflateStream or ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Compress.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.None
member.summary: None means that the data will be simply stored, with no change at all. If you are producing ZIPs for use on Mac OSX, be aware that archives produced with CompressionLevel.None cannot be opened with the default zip reader. Use a different CompressionLevel.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level0
member.summary: Same as None.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.BestSpeed
member.summary: The fastest but least effective compression.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level1
member.summary: A synonym for BestSpeed.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level2
member.summary: A little slower, but better, than level 1.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level3
member.summary: A little slower, but better, than level 2.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level4
member.summary: A little slower, but better, than level 3.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level5
member.summary: A little slower than level 4, but with better compression.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Default
member.summary: The default compression level, with a good balance of speed and compression efficiency.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level6
member.summary: A synonym for Default.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level7
member.summary: Pretty good compression!

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level8
member.summary: Better compression than Level7!

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.BestCompression
member.summary: The "best" compression, where best means greatest reduction in size of the input data stream. This is also the slowest compression.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel.Level9
member.summary: A synonym for BestCompression.

member.name: T:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionStrategy
member.summary: Describes options for how the compression algorithm is executed. Different strategies work better on different sorts of data. The strategy parameter can affect the compression ratio and the speed of compression but not the correctness of the compresssion.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionStrategy.Default
member.summary: The default strategy is probably the best for normal data.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionStrategy.Filtered
member.summary: The Filtered strategy is intended to be used most effectively with data produced by a filter or predictor. By this definition, filtered data consists mostly of small values with a somewhat random distribution. In this case, the compression algorithm is tuned to compress them better. The effect of Filtered is to force more Huffman coding and less string matching; it is a half-step between Default and HuffmanOnly.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.CompressionStrategy.HuffmanOnly
member.summary: Using HuffmanOnly will force the compressor to do Huffman encoding only, with no string matching.

member.name: T:Ionic.Zlib.Adler
member.summary: Computes an Adler-32 checksum.
member.remarks: The Adler checksum is similar to a CRC checksum, but faster to compute, though less reliable. It is used in producing RFC1950 compressed streams. The Adler checksum is a required part of the "ZLIB" standard. Applications will almost never need to use this class directly.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.Adler.Adler32(System.UInt32,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the Adler32 checksum.

remarks.para: This is used within ZLIB. You probably don't need to use this directly.

member.name: T:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec
member.summary: Encoder and Decoder for ZLIB and DEFLATE (IETF RFC1950 and RFC1951).
member.remarks: This class compresses and decompresses data according to the Deflate algorithm and optionally, the ZLIB format, as documented in RFC 1950 - ZLIB and RFC 1951 - DEFLATE.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.InputBuffer
member.summary: The buffer from which data is taken.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.NextIn
member.summary: An index into the InputBuffer array, indicating where to start reading.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.AvailableBytesIn
member.summary: The number of bytes available in the InputBuffer, starting at NextIn.
member.remarks: Generally you should set this to InputBuffer.Length before the first Inflate() or Deflate() call. The class will update this number as calls to Inflate/Deflate are made.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.TotalBytesIn
member.summary: Total number of bytes read so far, through all calls to Inflate()/Deflate().

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.OutputBuffer
member.summary: Buffer to store output data.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.NextOut
member.summary: An index into the OutputBuffer array, indicating where to start writing.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.AvailableBytesOut
member.summary: The number of bytes available in the OutputBuffer, starting at NextOut.
member.remarks: Generally you should set this to OutputBuffer.Length before the first Inflate() or Deflate() call. The class will update this number as calls to Inflate/Deflate are made.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.TotalBytesOut
member.summary: Total number of bytes written to the output so far, through all calls to Inflate()/Deflate().

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.Message
member.summary: used for diagnostics, when something goes wrong!

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.CompressLevel
member.summary: The compression level to use in this codec. Useful only in compression mode.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.WindowBits
member.summary: The number of Window Bits to use.
member.remarks: This gauges the size of the sliding window, and hence the compression effectiveness as well as memory consumption. It's best to just leave this setting alone if you don't know what it is. The maximum value is 15 bits, which implies a 32k window.

member.name: F:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.Strategy
member.summary: The compression strategy to use.
member.remarks: This is only effective in compression. The theory offered by ZLIB is that different strategies could potentially produce significant differences in compression behavior for different data sets. Unfortunately I don't have any good recommendations for how to set it differently. When I tested changing the strategy I got minimally different compression performance. It's best to leave this property alone if you don't have a good feel for it. Or, you may want to produce a test harness that runs through the different strategy options and evaluates them on different file types. If you do that, let me know your results.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.Adler32
member.summary: The Adler32 checksum on the data transferred through the codec so far. You probably don't need to look at this.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.#ctor
member.summary: Create a ZlibCodec.
member.remarks: If you use this default constructor, you will later have to explicitly call InitializeInflate() or InitializeDeflate() before using the ZlibCodec to compress or decompress.

member.summary: Create a ZlibCodec that either compresses or decompresses.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate
member.summary: Initialize the inflation state.
member.remarks: It is not necessary to call this before using the ZlibCodec to inflate data; It is implicitly called when you call the constructor.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initialize the inflation state with an explicit flag to govern the handling of RFC1950 header bytes.
member.remarks: By default, the ZLIB header defined in RFC 1950 is expected. If you want to read a zlib stream you should specify true for expectRfc1950Header. If you have a deflate stream, you will want to specify false. It is only necessary to invoke this initializer explicitly if you want to specify false.
member.param: whether to expect an RFC1950 header byte pair when reading the stream of data to be inflated.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialize the ZlibCodec for inflation, with the specified number of window bits.
member.param: The number of window bits to use. If you need to ask what that is, then you shouldn't be calling this initializer.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initialize the inflation state with an explicit flag to govern the handling of RFC1950 header bytes.
member.remarks: If you want to read a zlib stream you should specify true for expectRfc1950Header. In this case, the library will expect to find a ZLIB header, as defined in RFC 1950, in the compressed stream. If you will be reading a DEFLATE or GZIP stream, which does not have such a header, you will want to specify false.
member.param: whether to expect an RFC1950 header byte pair when reading the stream of data to be inflated.
The number of window bits to use. If you need to ask what that is, then you shouldn't be calling this initializer.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.Inflate(Ionic.Zlib.FlushType)
member.summary: Inflate the data in the InputBuffer, placing the result in the OutputBuffer.
member.remarks: You must have set InputBuffer and OutputBuffer, NextIn and NextOut, and AvailableBytesIn and AvailableBytesOut before calling this method.
member.param: The flush to use when inflating.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.EndInflate
member.summary: Ends an inflation session.
member.remarks: Call this after successively calling Inflate(). This will cause all buffers to be flushed. After calling this you cannot call Inflate() without a intervening call to one of the InitializeInflate() overloads.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.SyncInflate
member.summary: I don't know what this does!
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.InitializeDeflate
member.summary: Initialize the ZlibCodec for deflation operation.
member.remarks: The codec will use the MAX window bits and the default level of compression.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well. You generally don't need to check the return code.

member.summary: Initialize the ZlibCodec for deflation operation, using the specified CompressionLevel.
member.remarks: The codec will use the maximum window bits (15) and the specified CompressionLevel. It will emit a ZLIB stream as it compresses.
member.param: The compression level for the codec.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.remarks: The codec will use the maximum window bits (15) and the specified CompressionLevel. If you want to generate a zlib stream, you should specify true for wantRfc1950Header. In this case, the library will emit a ZLIB header, as defined in RFC 1950, in the compressed stream.
member.param: The compression level for the codec.
whether to emit an initial RFC1950 byte pair in the compressed stream.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.InitializeDeflate(Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel,System.Int32)

the number of window bits to use. If you don't know what this means, don't use this method.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.InitializeDeflate(Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel,System.Int32,System.Boolean)

whether to emit an initial RFC1950 byte pair in the compressed stream.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.Deflate(Ionic.Zlib.FlushType)
member.summary: Deflate one batch of data.
member.remarks: You must have set InputBuffer and OutputBuffer before calling this method.
member.param: whether to flush all data as you deflate. Generally you will want to use Z_NO_FLUSH here, in a series of calls to Deflate(), and then call EndDeflate() to flush everything.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.EndDeflate
member.summary: End a deflation session.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibCodec.ResetDeflate
member.summary: Reset a codec for another deflation session.
member.remarks: Call this to reset the deflation state. For example if a thread is deflating non-consecutive blocks, you can call Reset() after the Deflate(Sync) of the first block and before the next Deflate(None) of the second block.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

the strategy to use for compression.

member.name: T:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream
member.summary: Represents a Zlib stream for compression or decompression.

remarks.para: The ZlibStream is a Decorator on a . It adds ZLIB compression or decompression to any stream.

Using this stream, applications can compress or decompress data via stream Read() and Write() operations. Either compresssion or decompression can occur through either reading or writing. The compression format used is ZLIB, which is documented in IETF RFC 1950, "ZLIB Compressed Data Format Specification version 3.3". This implementation of ZLIB always uses DEFLATE as the compression method. (see IETF RFC 1951, "DEFLATE Compressed Data Format Specification version 1.3.")

The ZLIB format allows for varying compression methods, window sizes, and dictionaries. This implementation always uses the DEFLATE compression method, a preset dictionary, and 15 window bits by default.

This class is similar to , except that it adds the RFC1950 header and trailer bytes to a compressed stream when compressing, or expects the RFC1950 header and trailer bytes when decompressing. It is also similar to the .

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionMode)
member.summary: Create a ZlibStream using the specified CompressionMode.

remarks.para: When mode is CompressionMode.Compress, the ZlibStream will use the default compression level. The "captive" stream will be closed when the ZlibStream is closed.

member.param: The stream which will be read or written.
Indicates whether the ZlibStream will compress or decompress.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionMode,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel)
member.summary: Create a ZlibStream using the specified CompressionMode and the specified CompressionLevel.

remarks.para: When mode is CompressionMode.Decompress, the level parameter is ignored. The "captive" stream will be closed when the ZlibStream is closed.

member.param: The stream to be read or written while deflating or inflating.
Indicates whether the ZlibStream will compress or decompress.
A tuning knob to trade speed for effectiveness.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionMode,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a ZlibStream using the specified CompressionMode, and explicitly specify whether the captive stream should be left open after Deflation or Inflation.

remarks.para: When mode is CompressionMode.Compress, the ZlibStream will use the default compression level.

This constructor allows the application to request that the captive stream remain open after the deflation or inflation occurs. By default, after Close() is called on the stream, the captive stream is also closed. In some cases this is not desired, for example if the stream is a that will be re-read after compression. Specify true for the parameter to leave the stream open.
See the other overloads of this constructor for example code.

member.param: The stream which will be read or written. This is called the "captive" stream in other places in this documentation.
Indicates whether the ZlibStream will compress or decompress.
true if the application would like the stream to remain open after inflation/deflation.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionMode,Ionic.Zlib.CompressionLevel,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a ZlibStream using the specified CompressionMode and the specified CompressionLevel, and explicitly specify whether the stream should be left open after Deflation or Inflation.

remarks.para: This constructor allows the application to request that the captive stream remain open after the deflation or inflation occurs. By default, after Close() is called on the stream, the captive stream is also closed. In some cases this is not desired, for example if the stream is a that will be re-read after compression. Specify true for the parameter to leave the stream open.
When mode is CompressionMode.Decompress, the level parameter is ignored.

member.param: The stream which will be read or written.
Indicates whether the ZlibStream will compress or decompress.
true if the application would like the stream to remain open after inflation/deflation.
A tuning knob to trade speed for effectiveness. This parameter is effective only when mode is CompressionMode.Compress.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.FlushMode
member.summary: This property sets the flush behavior on the stream. Sorry, though, not sure exactly how to describe all the various settings.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.BufferSize
member.summary: The size of the working buffer for the compression codec.

remarks.para: The working buffer is used for all stream operations. The default size is 1024 bytes. The minimum size is 128 bytes. You may get better performance with a larger buffer. Then again, you might not. You would have to test it.
Set this before the first call to Read() or Write() on the stream. If you try to set it afterwards, it will throw.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.TotalIn
member.summary: Returns the total number of bytes input so far.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.TotalOut
member.summary: Returns the total number of bytes output so far.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Dispose the stream.

remarks.para: This may or may not result in a Close() call on the captive stream. See the constructors that have a leaveOpen parameter for more information.

This method may be invoked in two distinct scenarios. If disposing == true, the method has been called directly or indirectly by a user's code, for example via the public Dispose() method. In this case, both managed and unmanaged resources can be referenced and disposed. If disposing == false, the method has been called by the runtime from inside the object finalizer and this method should not reference other objects; in that case only unmanaged resources must be referenced or disposed.

member.param: indicates whether the Dispose method was invoked by user code.

member.summary: Indicates whether the stream can be read.
member.remarks: The return value depends on whether the captive stream supports reading.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.CanSeek
member.summary: Indicates whether the stream supports Seek operations.
member.remarks: Always returns false.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.CanWrite
member.summary: Indicates whether the stream can be written.
member.remarks: The return value depends on whether the captive stream supports writing.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.Flush
member.summary: Flush the stream.

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.Length
member.summary: Reading this property always throws a .

member.name: P:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.Position
member.summary: The position of the stream pointer.
member.remarks: Setting this property always throws a . Reading will return the total bytes written out, if used in writing, or the total bytes read in, if used in reading. The count may refer to compressed bytes or uncompressed bytes, depending on how you've used the stream.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Read data from the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the ZlibStream to compress data while reading, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Compress, providing an uncompressed data stream. Then call Read() on that ZlibStream, and the data read will be compressed. If you wish to use the ZlibStream to decompress data while reading, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Decompress, providing a readable compressed data stream. Then call Read() on that ZlibStream, and the data will be decompressed as it is read.
A ZlibStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both.

member.param: The buffer into which the read data should be placed.
the offset within that data array to put the first byte read.
the number of bytes to read.
member.returns: the number of bytes read

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.Seek(System.Int64,System.IO.SeekOrigin)
member.summary: Calling this method always throws a .
member.param: The offset to seek to.... IF THIS METHOD ACTUALLY DID ANYTHING.
The reference specifying how to apply the offset.... IF THIS METHOD ACTUALLY DID ANYTHING.
member.returns: nothing. This method always throws.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.SetLength(System.Int64)
member.summary: Calling this method always throws a .
member.param: The new value for the stream length.... IF THIS METHOD ACTUALLY DID ANYTHING.

member.name: M:Ionic.Zlib.ZlibStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Write data to the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the ZlibStream to compress data while writing, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Compress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that ZlibStream, providing uncompressed data as input. The data sent to the output stream will be the compressed form of the data written. If you wish to use the ZlibStream to decompress data while writing, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Decompress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that stream, providing previously compressed data. The data sent to the output stream will be the decompressed form of the data written.
A ZlibStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both.

member.param: The buffer holding data to write to the stream.
the offset within that data array to find the first byte to write.
the number of bytes to write.
